newsitem.title: SWEDEN: Spain ranked most sinful country by Swedish paper.
newsitem.headline: Spain ranked most sinful country by Swedish paper.

text.p: A Swedish survey on Friday cast Spain as the most sinful nation among a group of leading industrialised countries.

The list, compiled by export journal Svensk Export Strategi as a guide for travelling businessmen, ranked 19 nations according to seven modern deadly sins - smoking, drinking, drugs, gambling, lavish eating, nightlife and prostitution.
Spain was the clear winner, topping both nightlife and gambling categories but the Nordic countries -- Sweden, Finland and Norway -- were bottom of the sin list.
"The concept of sinful Sweden in the 1950s and 1960s was just an illusion," Strategi said.
"The Swedish authorities have protected the Swedes from many temptations," it said wryly.
However, the paper said Spain had become a den of vice in the post-Franco era.

"Previously Spaniards had a siesta to avoid the middday heat. These days they sleep late into the morning in order to recover from their nocturnal exploits... going out to restaurants at ten in the evening," the paper said.
France was the second most wicked country, with the highest per capital consumption of alcohol, Strategi said.
The United States was third on the list. Its drug abuse problem was the worst out of the 19 countries and America also had the highest number of expensive restaurants and hotels.
Prostitution was most prolific in the Netherlands, which was ranked fifth in the vice list after Britain, but scarcest in Ireland, 14th on the list of sinfullness.
Denmark, where it is fashionable for women to smoke cigarillos, had the most smokers, and ranked sixth.
Germany was listed seventh followed by Austria, Belgium, Italy, Switzerland, Luxembourg and Greece. Portugal came 17th followed by Japan, which was second worst in the smoking stakes.
